messageBody:
Test Isolation

The constructor is run once, setUp (or @Before) is run before each test method. If you want to make sure each test has the same setup/configuration before the test executes, put it in setUp. If, on the other hand, you want to make sure all tests in a test case use the same values, put it in the constructor.

Constructor E.G.: I want to use a common DAO for all tests. Initialize it in the CTOR

setUp E.G.: I want to create a new instance of Foo for every test. I put it in setUp so a test can change it, I init it in setUp so one test does not affect the next one (I use this frequently)

You really need setUp. The constructor is a nice plus.

You can alternatively clean up using tearDown.

I have a large set of examples at http://schuchert.wikispaces.com/Car+Rental+Example. The included zip file has 100 Unit Tests (more on that in another message). But if you have a look at VehicleComponentTest, you'll see the following:
@Before
public void init() {
vehicle = generateVehicle();
}

Every test in that class uses this vehicle variable. Sure I could put that same line in every test, but this is a simple example. Another more complex example: VehicleTypeComponentTest:
@Before
public void setup() {
component = CarRentalBeanFactory.getBean(VehicleTypeComponent.class);
component.removeAll();
createAndInstallVehicleType(PRE_EXISTING_1, MAKE, MODEL, YEAR, ValidState.valid);
createAndInstallVehicleType(PRE_EXISTING_2, MAKE, MODEL, YEAR, ValidState.valid);
createAndInstallVehicleType(PRE_EXISTING_3, MAKE, MODEL, YEAR, ValidState.invalid);
createAndInstallVehicleType(PRE_EXISTING_4, MAKE, MODEL, YEAR, ValidState.valid);
}

I want to start with a fresh set of known values (four VehicleTypes in this case) before each test. Not every test uses all of these, but I have them as I write new tests.

Since it is possible for a test to change one of these VehicleTypes, I reinstall them for each test so that tests run in isolation.

Brett

Subject: [junit] setUp versus constructors


I've been using JUnit for a few years now, and one thing that's always
bothered me is the "setUp" method.

I always do my initialization in my constructor (if I'm not just doing
it at the field definition) as constructors allow me to initialize
final fields. The semantics of using a constructor also seem far more
obvious to me as everyone reading my code knows Java, while not
everyone is a JUnit guru.

The additional complexity of having the (as far as I can tell)
redundant setUp method seems counterproductive, so why does setUp exist?
